'''Samir Nasri''' (born 26 June 1987) is a French professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Premier League]] club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2018/december/31-december/hammers-sign-premier-league-title-winner-samir-nasri#PZ9BP8w8UUAbE9Xb.99 |title=Hammers sign Premier League title winner Samir Nasri|author=<!--Not stated--> |date=31 December 2018 |website=whufc.com |publisher=West Ham United |access-date=31 December 2018 |quote=}}</ref> He primarily plays as an [[attacking midfielder]] and a [[Winger (association football)|winger]], although he has also been deployed in [[Centre midfielder|central midfield]]. He was suspended from football for eighteen months until January 2019 following a [[doping (sport)|doping]] violation.
Nasri is known for his dribbling, ball control and passing ability.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/aug/17/arsenalnasriwestbrom|title=Nasri makes an instant impact |work=The Guardian |date=17 August 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | location=London| first=Amy| last=Lawrence}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2010/mar/13/samir-nasri-dribbling-stanley-matthews|title=Samir Nasri's dribbling makes him a throwback to days of Matthews|work=The Guardian |date=13 March 2010 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | location=London| first=David| last=Lacey}}</ref> He is described as a player whose "vision and imagination make him an unpredictable opponent".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/player/_/id/43531/Samir-Nasri?cc=5901|title=Samir Nasri ESPN Bio |publisher=[[ESPN]]|date= |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref> His playing style, ability and cultural background have drawn comparisons to French legend [[Zinedine Zidane]].<ref name="nasri_zidane">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/mar/23/europeanfootball.marseille|title=Samir Nasri: the new Zidane?|work=The Guardian |date=23 March 2007 |accessdate=3 June 2010 | location=London| first=Paul| last=Doyle}}</ref><ref name="nasri_interview">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1362722/Samir-Nasri-Arsenal-star-argument-Thierry-Henry-problems-William-Gallas.html|title=Nasri: We had an argument but Thierry was cool – then I had a problem with Gallas |date=4 March 2011 |work=Daily Mail |location=UK|accessdate=19 March 2011 |first=Matt |last=Lawton}}</ref>
Nasri began his football career playing for local youth clubs in his hometown [[Marseille]]. At age nine, he joined professional club [[Olympique de Marseille]] and spent the next seven years developing in the club's youth academy at [[Centre d'entraînement Robert Louis-Dreyfus|La Commanderie]], the club's training centre. In the [[2004–05 Ligue 1|2004–05 season]], he made his professional debut in September 2004 at age 17 against [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]]. In the [[2005–06 Ligue 1|following season]], he became a regular starter in the team and also participated in [[UEFA|European competition]] for the first time after playing in the [[2005–06 UEFA Cup|2005–06 edition]] of the [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]]. In the [[2006–07 Ligue 1|2006–07 campaign]], Nasri won the [[National Union of Professional Footballers]] (UNFP) [[Trophées UNFP du football#Young Player of the Year|Young Player of the Year]] award and was also named to the [[Trophées UNFP du football#Team of the Year|Team of the Year]]. He finished his career with Marseille amassing over 160 appearances. He played in the teams that reached back-to-back [[Coupe de France]] finals in [[2006 Coupe de France Final|2006]] and [[2007 Coupe de France Final|2007]].
In June 2008, Nasri joined [[Premier League]] club [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on a four-year contract. He reached prominence with the team in his third season winning the [[Professional Footballers' Association]] (PFA) Fans' Player of the Month award on three occasions and being named to the association's [[PFA Team of the Year|Team of the Year]]. In December 2010, he was named the [[France Football#French Player of the Year|French Player of the Year]] for his performances during the calendar year.<ref name="nasri_player">{{cite web |url=http://www.francefootball.fr/FF/breves2010/20101213_144746_nasri-numero-1-a-23-ans.html |title=Nasri, numéro 1 à 23 ans |work=[[France Football]] |date=13 December 2010 |accessdate=13 December 2010 |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101214104656/http://www.francefootball.fr/FF/breves2010/20101213_144746_nasri-numero-1-a-23-ans.html |archivedate=14 December 2010 }}</ref> In August 2011, after three seasons with Arsenal, Nasri joined [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] on a four-year contract. In his first season with the club, he won his first major honour as a player as the club won the [[2011–12 Premier League]].
Nasri is a former [[France national youth football team|France youth international]] and has represented his nation at every level for which he was eligible. Prior to playing for the [[France national football team|senior team]], he played on the [[France national under-17 football team|under-17 team]] that won the [[2004 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]]. Nasri made his senior international debut in March 2007 in a friendly match against [[Austria national football team|Austria]]. Two months later, he scored his first senior international goal in a 1–0 [[UEFA Euro 2008 qualifying]] win over [[Georgia national football team|Georgia]]. Nasri has represented France at two major international tournaments: [[UEFA Euro 2008]] and [[UEFA Euro 2012|Euro 2012]].
== Personal life == Samir Nasri ({{lang-ar|سمير نصري}}) was born in [[Septèmes-les-Vallons]], a northern suburb of [[Marseille]], to French nationals of [[Algeria]]n descent.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://septemesmonvillage.free.fr/septemois/samir-nasri%20.html|title=Le minot Prodige de Septèmes |publisher=[[Septèmes-les-Vallons]]|date= |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref><ref name="nasri_parents">{{cite news |url=http://www.liberation.fr/portrait/0101101885-petit-om-deviendra-grand|title=Petit OM deviendra grand |publisher=[[Septèmes-les-Vallons]]|date=11 May 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> His mother, Ouassila Ben Saïd, and father, Abdelhafid Nasri, were both born in France; his father being born and raised in Marseille, while his mother being from nearby [[Salon-de-Provence]].<ref name="nasri_parents"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.rmcsport.fr/editorial/262422/nasri-un-bleu-made-in-om/|title=Nasri, un Bleu "made in OM" |publisher=[[Radio Monte Carlo|RMC Sport]]|date=2 June 2012 |accessdate=2 June 2012 | language = French }}</ref> Nasri's grandparents emigrated to France from Algeria.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.purepeople.com/article/samir-nasri-et-tatiana-golovin-si-demain-tatiana-m-apprenait-qu-elle-attend-un-enfant_a50649/1|title=Samir Nasri et Tatiana Golovin: "Si demain Tatiana m'apprenait qu'elle attend un enfant ..." |work=Pure People|date=24 February 2010 |accessdate=19 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> His mother is a [[housewife]] and his father previously worked as a [[bus driver]] before becoming his son's personal manager. At the start of his football career, Nasri initially played under his mother's surname, Ben Saïd, before switching to Nasri, his father's surname, following his selection to the [[France national under-16 football team|France under-16 team]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/bleus/actu/384113.shtml |title=Samir Nasri fête ses 20 ans |publisher=[[French Football Federation]] |date=26 June 2007 |accessdate=8 February 2012 | language = French }}</ref> He is the eldest of four children and is a non-practising Muslim.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lebuteur.com/international/actualites/samir-nasri-je-suis-musulman-non-pratiquant|title=Samir Nasri: "Je suis musulman, non pratiquant"|work=Le Buteur|date=5 March 2011|accessdate=27 March 2011|language=French|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110308230635/http://www.lebuteur.com/international/actualites/samir-nasri-je-suis-musulman-non-pratiquant|archivedate=8 March 2011}}</ref> Nasri has a younger sister named Sonia and twin brothers named Walid and Malik.<ref name="nasri_parents"/> All four were raised in La Gavotte Peyret. After joining [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in England, Nasri settled in [[Hampstead]], a district of North London.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/samir-nasri-gunners-midfielder-is-streets-ahead-1625716.html|title=Samir Nasri: Gunners midfielder is streets ahead |work=The Independent |location=UK|date=19 February 2009 |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref>
== Club career ==
=== Early career === While growing up in La Gavotte Peyret, Nasri grew an attraction to the sport of [[association football|football]] at a young age.<ref name="nasri_interview"/> He regularly played the sport on the [[street football|streets]] where he learned many of his skills. Upon noticing his prodigious talent, his parents signed him up to play with the local club in his hometown. Nasri spent one year playing with the club in La Gavotte Peyret before moving to Pennes Mirabeau in nearby [[Les Pennes-Mirabeau|Mirabeau]] at age seven. While playing with Pennes, Nasri was discovered by [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] scout Freddy Assolen, who had been informed of the player's talent through local [[word of mouth]].<ref name="nasri_parents"/><ref name="nasri_assolen">{{cite news|url=http://www.om.net/en/Saison/101002/Actualites/32981/Samir_Nasri_to_play_his_100th|title=Samir Nasri to play his 100th!|publisher=[[Olympique de Marseille]]|date=10 November 2007|accessdate=18 March 2011|language=French|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120405021025/http://www.om.net/en/Saison/101002/Actualites/32981/Samir_Nasri_to_play_his_100th|archivedate=5 April 2012}}</ref> After noticing Nasri's skill in person, Assolen recruited the player to travel with a group of other young players to Italy to participate in a youth tournament where they would play against the youth academies of [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] and [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]]. Nasri impressed at the tournament and Assolen was jokingly told by a Milan scout that "he [Nasri] stays here, you leave him".<ref name="nasri_parents"/> After returning to France, Marseille officials organized a meeting with the player's father and the group agreed to allow Nasri insertion into the club's academy at the age of nine.
=== Olympique de Marseille ===
{{Quote box | width=30% | align=right | quote= "He could do everything with the ball: stepovers, dribbling, shooting with the right or the left. In fact, I wasn't even sure whether he was left or right-footed." |source= <small>Freddy Assolen, upon noticing Nasri's skill at the age of nine.<ref name="nasri_assolen"/> </small> }}
Upon entering the Marseille youth academy, Nasri quickly impressed. Upon moving to [[Bastide]], where the club's youth players reside, his style of play began to take shape. In 2007, Nasri admitted that the move to Bastide really helped his game, stating, "That's where I really started to progress. Training was different and the facilities are beautiful, all of which helps you work well."<ref name="nasri_assolen"/> As a result of his quick progression, Nasri was an integral part of every youth team he was a part of winning several trophies, such as the Championnat de Provence, Coupe de Provence, and the Ligue de la Méditerranée. After spending most of the 2003–04 season playing with the club's under-18 team, for the latter part of the season, the now 16-year-old Nasri was promoted to the club's reserve team in the [[Championnat de France amateur]], the fourth division of [[Football in France|French football]]. He appeared primarily as a substitute in a few matches during the campaign as the reserve team failed to rebound from its bad start to the season, which resulted in a 16th-place finish and relegation to the [[Championnat de France amateur 2]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stat2foot.com/mclubs/om20304.htm|title=Olympique Marseille Reserve Pro: Saison Football 2003/2004|work=Stat2Foot|date=|accessdate=18 March 2011|language=French|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120617131754/http://www.stat2foot.com/mclubs/om20304.htm#|archive-date=17 June 2012|dead-url=yes}}</ref>
==== Debut season ==== Ahead of the [[2004–05 Ligue 1|2004–05 season]], several clubs were reported to be interested in signing Nasri, most notably English clubs [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11670_2337629,00.html|title=Gunners join Nasri hunt |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=31 May 2005 |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref> In an effort to decrease the speculation, Nasri was offered a three-year professional contract by Marseille officials led by president [[Pape Diouf]] and manager [[José Anigo]]. On 13 August 2004, Nasri agreed to the contract. Marseille officials had been eager to sign Nasri to a contract in an attempt to not undergo a situation similar to the departure of [[Mathieu Flamini]], in which the player departed the club without Marseille receiving any compensation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11669_2323845,00.html|title=L'OM starlet in demand |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=14 January 2005 |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref> As a result of his professional contract, Nasri was promoted to the senior team by Anigo and assigned the number 22 shirt. He began the season playing on the club's reserve team and appeared in four matches before earning a call up to the senior team in September 2004.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stat2foot.com/mclubs/om20405.htm|title=Olympique Marseille Reserve Pro: Saison Football 2004/2005|work=Stat2Foot|date=|accessdate=22 March 2011|language=French|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402031819/http://www.stat2foot.com/mclubs/om20405.htm#|archive-date=2 April 2012|dead-url=yes}}</ref>
Nasri made his professional debut on 12 September in a 2–0 league defeat to [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]], appearing as a substitute for [[Bruno Cheyrou]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/49233|title=Sochaux v. Marseille Match Report|publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=12 September 2004 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> On 17 October, he made his first professional start playing the entire match in a 1–1 draw with [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/48917|title=Marseille v. Saint-Étienne Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=17 October 2004 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> Nasri featured heavily within the team under Anigo and later [[Philippe Troussier]]. In the team's first match following the winter break, he scored his first professional goal in a 2–1 away victory over [[Lille OSC|Lille]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/49211|title=Lille v. Marseille Match Report|publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=11 January 2005 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> Nasri finished his rookie campaign with 25 total appearances, one goal and two assists.
==== 2005–06 season ====
[[File:Samir Nasri in Moscow.jpg|200px|upright|thumb|left|Nasri taking a corner during his time with Marseille.]]
The [[2005–06 Ligue 1|2005–06 season]] saw Marseille boosted by the arrival of attackers [[Franck Ribéry]] and [[Djibril Cissé]], the latter arriving after having a successful loan stint with the club the previous season. Nasri, who was now given a more prominent role within the team by new manager [[Jean Fernandez]], formed impressive partnerships with the two along with lead [[Striker (association football)|striker]] [[Mamadou Niang]].<ref name="nasri_assolen"/> He appeared in 49 total matches, which included appearances in both the [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]] and the [[UEFA Intertoto Cup]]. Nasri made his European debut on 16 July 2005 in the first round of the [[2005 UEFA Intertoto Cup]] against Swiss club [[BSC Young Boys|Young Boys]]. Marseille won the first leg 3–2. In the second leg, Nasri scored his first European goal in a 2–1 win. Marseille ultimately won the competition after beating Spanish outfit [[Deportivo de La Coruña]] 5–3 on aggregate. In the league, Nasri appeared in 30 matches, 25 as a starter. He scored his only league goal of the season on 29 April 2007 in a 4–2 win over Sochaux.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/50817|title=Marseille v. Sochaux Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=11 January 2005 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> In the [[Coupe de France]], Nasri appeared in five matches as Marseille reached the final of the competition where the club faced ''[[Le Classique]]'' rivals [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]]. Nasri appeared as a substitute in the match as Marseille were defeated 2–1. Following the season, Nasri signed a two-year contract extension with the club until 2009.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11668_2343857,00.html|title=l'OM starlets sign on |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=2 August 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref>
==== 2006–07 season ==== Nasri began the [[2006–07 Ligue 1|2006–07 season]] playing under [[Albert Emon]], his fourth different manager in three years. Despite this, Marseille's now heightened popularity saw increased speculation from writers and supporters that the club would finally win its first league title since the [[1991–92 French Division 1|1991–92 season]]. Nasri began the season on a quick note scoring the second goal in the team's 3–1 win over Paris Saint-Germain in September 2006.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/50565|title=Paris Saint-Germain v. Marseille Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=10 September 2006 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> On 29 April 2007, Nasri scored a goal in Marseille's 4–2 hammering of Sochaux.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/50817|title=Marseille v. Sochaux Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=29 April 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> Marseille were due to face the same club in the [[2007 Coupe de France Final]] just days later and were, subsequently, heavy favorites as a result of the team's two-goal victory in the previous match. However, Sochaux recorded an upset victory defeating Marseille 5–4 on [[Penalty shootout (association football)|penalties]] after the match ended 2–2 following extra time. On the final match day of the season, Nasri converted the only goal in a 1–0 win over [[CS Sedan Ardennes|Sedan]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/50846|title=Marseille v. Sedan Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=26 May 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> The victory secured 2nd place for Marseille and was the club's best finish since finishing runner-up to Bordeaux in the [[1998–99 French Division 1|1998–99 season]]. Nasri finished the season with a career-high 50 appearances, 37 of them in the league. For his efforts, he was awarded the [[National Union of Professional Footballers|UNFP]] [[Trophées UNFP du football#Young Player of the Year|Young Player of the Year]] award and named to the [[Trophées UNFP du football#Team of the Year|Team of the Year]].<ref name="nasri_honours">{{cite news |url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/samir-nasri-my-reasons-for-joining-arsenal|title=Samir Nasri – My reasons for joining Arsenal |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=11 July 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> Nasri was also voted the Club Player of the Year by supporters, receiving 62% of the votes ahead of the likes of Ribéry and Niang.<ref name="nasri_honours"/>
==== 2007–08 season ====
[[File:SamirNasri.jpg|175px|upright|thumb|right|Nasri with Marseille in 2008.]]
Similar to his previous three years at Marseille, Nasri began the new season under new management as the club was now being led by the Belgian [[Eric Gerets]]. Due to the departure of Ribéry to [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]], Gerets installed Nasri as the focal point of the attack and he responding by having his best season at the club. He appeared in 42 total matches scoring a career-high six goals and also assisting on a career-high 15 goals. Nasri formed partnerships in the midfield with winger [[Mathieu Valbuena]] and [[midfielders]] [[Lorik Cana]] and [[Benoît Cheyrou]] as Marseille boasted the third-best attack in the league behind champions [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]] and [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]], who finished first and second in the league respectively. Initially, Nasri struggled during the infancy of the campaign due to dealing with the effects of a severely sprained ankle suffered in the pre-season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11810_2595419,00.html|title=L'OM relief at Nasri news |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=10 July 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref> He failed to score a goal or provide an assist in the team's first eight league matches. On 24 November 2007, he assisted on two goals in a 2–0 victory over [[FC Metz|Metz]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51412|title=Marseille v. Metz Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=24 November 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> Nasri closed out the fall season by assisting on the equalizing goal in a 2–2 draw with Bordeaux and making the final pass on the match-winning goal against [[Le Mans FC|Le Mans]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51671|title=Bordeaux v. Marseille Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=16 December 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51412|title=Marseille v. Le Mans Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=22 December 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref>
Following the winter break, Nasri's goal-scoring began to take form. In late January, he scored goals in back-to-back matches against [[AS Nancy|Nancy]] and [[Stade Malherbe Caen|Caen]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51469|title=Nancy v. Marseille Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=23 January 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51478|title=Marseille v. Caen Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=26 January 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> In European competition, Nasri participated in the [[UEFA Champions League]] for the first time in his career, however he failed to make an impact in the four group stage matches he appeared in. He missed the club's upset victory over Liverpool at [[Anfield]] due to dealing with a bout of [[meningitis]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11800_2754445,00.html|title=Nasri setback for Marseille |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=25 September 2007|accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11800_2845112,00.html|title=Nasri set for Marseille return |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=29 September 2007|accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/history/season=2008/round=15105/match=301175/report=rp.html |title=Gerets enjoys dream start at Anfield |date=3 October 2007 |accessdate=16 February 2011 |publisher=[[UEFA]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160116140030/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/history/season=2008/round=15105/match=301175/report=rp.html |archivedate=16 January 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/search_index.php?page=detail_news&news_id=13356|title=Liverpool on the ropes as Marseille storm fortress Anfield |date=4 October 2007 |accessdate=16 February 2011 |work=The Financial Express}}</ref> Marseille ultimately finished the group in third place, which resulted in the team qualifying for the round of 32 of the UEFA Cup. The club was defeated in the round of 16 by [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg|Zenit Saint Petersburg]] despite being up 3–1 heading into the second leg. Of those three goals Marseille scored in the first leg, Nasri assisted on two of them. On 16 March 2008, Nasri scored a goal in a 3–3 draw with [[RC Lens|Lens]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51529|title=Lens v. Marseille Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=16 March 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> A month later, he scored the game-winning goal in a 2–1 victory over Metz.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51572|title=Metz v. Marseille Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=12 April 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 | language = French }}</ref> In his final match with Marseille, against [[RC Strasbourg Alsace|Strasbourg]], Nasri scored a goal and assisted on another in a 4–3 victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51620 |title=Marseille v. Strasbourg Match Report |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=17 May 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318045451/http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/51620 |archivedate=18 March 2012 }}</ref> Marseille finished the league campaign in third place, which resulted in the club qualifying for the UEFA Champions League for the second consecutive season. On 8 May 2008, with all the transfer speculation surrounding the player, Nasri surprised many by signing a three-year contract extension with the club until 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11800_3537838,00.html|title=Nasri pens l'OM extension |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=8 May 2008 |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref>
=== Arsenal ===
==== 2008–09 season ====
{{Quote box | width=30% | align=left | quote= "Samir is a student of football – he lives for the game. He loves training and watches game after game on TV. He uses things he has seen to help correct mistakes in his own game. When you genuinely love football this is what makes the difference." |source= <small>[[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] scout [[Gilles Grimandi]] on Nasri.<ref name="nasri_scout">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/a/arsenal/9411158.stm |title=Gilles Grimandi profiles Manchester City's Samir Nasri |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 March 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2011 }}</ref> </small> }}
One week later, despite signing a contract extension with Marseille, Nasri was linked with a move to [[Premier League]] club Arsenal. Arsenal manager [[Arsène Wenger]] had been tracking Nasri since watching him play at the [[2004 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]].<ref name="nasri_scout"/> It was later revealed that the contract extension Nasri signed with Marseille was simply protocol to allow Marseille to receive a higher transfer fee for the player. The [[Bouches-du-Rhône]]-based club was seeking [[British pound|£]]14 million for the young midfielder.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11670_3573024,00.html|title=Gunners set sights on Nasri |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=18 May 2008 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref> Ahead of [[UEFA Euro 2008]], both Nasri's agent and Wenger admitted that offers were made for the player and that a move to the English club was imminent.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11670_3593431,00.html|title=Nasri reveals Arsenal offer |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=21 May 2008 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11670_3609039,00.html|title=Wenger – Nasri signing likely |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=25 May 2008 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref> The deal was ultimately concluded following the competition on 11 July 2008 with Nasri agreeing to a four-year contract.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11670_3805050,00.html|title=Arsenal seal Nasri capture |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=11 July 2008 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref> The transfer fee was undisclosed, but has been purported to be in the region of £12 million.<ref name="nasri_arsenal">{{cite news |url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/nasri-agrees-to-join-arsenal-from-marseille|title=Nasri agrees to join Arsenal from Marseille |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=11 July 2008 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref> Upon arriving at the club, Nasri admitted Wenger was one of the primary reasons for him joining the club: "The fact that Arsène Wenger gives great opportunities to young players is very important for me. Arsène has a great reputation and he is one of the best managers in the world."<ref name="nasri_honours"/>
[[File:Samir Nasri.jpg|thumb|upright|Nasri preparing to take a [[corner kick]] for [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].]]
Nasri was given the number 8 shirt – previously worn by Arsenal legends [[Ian Wright]], [[George Graham (footballer)|George Graham]], [[Alan Sunderland]] and [[Freddie Ljungberg]] – and made his club debut on 30 July 2008 in a friendly match against German club [[VfB Stuttgart]] in a 3–1 win.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11670_3888495,00.html|title=Nasri bow in Gunners win |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=30 July 2008 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.arsenal.com/match-menu/2976363/first-team/vfb-stuttgart-v-arsenal?tab=report|title=VfB Stuttgart v. Arsenal Match Report |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=30 July 2008 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref> He made his Premier League debut in the team's first match of [[2008–09 Premier League|the league season]] on 16 August against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]]. In the match, Nasri scored his first league goal scoring with a close-range effort, after four minutes in a 1–0 victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7551128.stm |title=Arsenal 1–0 West Brom |publisher=BBC | date = 16 August 2008 | first=Paul | last=Fletcher| accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> As a result of his debut goal, he became the 83rd player in Premier League history to score on his league debut and the 22nd Arsenal player.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/24717/|title=Nasri joins long list of League debut scorers |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=16 August 2008 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref> On 27 August, Nasri scored his second goal for the club in the team's [[2008–09 UEFA Champions League]] third round qualifying second leg tie against [[FC Twente|Twente]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/7578508.stm |title=Arsenal 4–0 FC Twente (agg 6–0) |publisher=BBC |date=27 August 2008 | first=Phil| last=McNulty| accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> Arsenal won the match 4–0 and the tie 6–0 on aggregate.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/history/season=2009/round=15275/match=303837/index.html |title=Rampant Arsenal cut down Twente |publisher=[[UEFA]] |date=27 August 2008 |accessdate=19 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160116140030/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/history/season=2009/round=15275/match=303837/index.html |archivedate=16 January 2016 }}</ref> On 8 November, Nasri scored both of Arsenal's goals in a 2–1 win over [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Nasri double reignites Arsenal's title challenge at expense of misfiring United|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/nov/08/arsenal-manchester-united-premier-league|work=The Guardian |date=8 November 2008 |first=Richard|last=Aikman | location=London| accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/match_report/0,19764,11065_3003756,00.html|title=Nasri brace lifts Gunners |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=8 November 2008 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref>
On 21 December, Nasri assisted on the opening goal scored by [[Robin van Persie]] in the team's 1–1 draw with Liverpool.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.arsenal.com/match-menu/3073790/first-team/arsenal-v-liverpool|title=Premier League: Arsenal 1–1 Liverpool -Report |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=21 December 2008 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref> Nasri returned to his scoring form in the new year. On 17 January 2009, he scored the second goal in the club's 3–1 win over [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] at the [[KC Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news|title= Wenger toys with a different route but Van Persie proves the pathfinder | url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/jan/18/hull-arsenal-arsene-wenger-robin-van-persie-premier-league-match-report |work=The Guardian |date=17 January 2009 |first=Jeremy |last=Alexander | location=London| accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> It took Nasri another two months to score another goal, which came in Arsenal's 3–1 away win against Newcastle United.<ref>{{cite news |title= Diaby deepens St James' Park gloom as Arsenal coast |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/mar/21/premier-league-newcastle-united-arsenal |date=21 March 2009 |first=Tim |last=Rich |work=The Guardian | location=London| accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> He finished his first campaign at Arsenal appearing in 44 matches, scoring seven goals and providing five assists.
==== 2009–10 season ==== On 21 July 2009, while participating in a training match during pre-season with Arsenal in [[Bad Waltersdorf]], Nasri suffered a [[broken leg]]. The injury required two to three months of rest and, as a result, Nasri missed the opening of the [[2009–10 Premier League]] season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11661_5446588,00.html|title=Nasri suffers broken leg |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |date=21 July 2009 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref> He made his debut late in the campaign on 25 October 2009 in a [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] tie against Liverpool. Nasri played the entire match in a 2–1 win.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.arsenal.com/match-menu/3203881/first-team/arsenal-v-liverpool|title=Goals from Merida and Bendtner see Gunners into Quarter-Final |date=25 October 2009 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref> On 4 November, he scored his first goal of the season in the team's [[2009–10 UEFA Champions League group stage]] match against [[AZ Alkmaar|AZ]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/fixturesresults/round=2000028/match=2000418/index.html |title=Clinical Arsenal brush AZ aside |publisher=[[UEFA]] |date=4 November 2009 |accessdate=19 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160116140030/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/fixturesresults/round=2000028/match=2000418/index.html |archivedate=16 January 2016 }}</ref> Three weeks later, Nasri converted another Champions League goal, this time against [[Standard Liège]] in a 2–0 win.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/fixturesresults/round=2000028/match=2000443/index.html |title=Assured Arsenal ease through |publisher=[[UEFA]] |date=24 November 2009 |accessdate=19 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160116140030/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/fixturesresults/round=2000028/match=2000443/index.html |archivedate=16 January 2016 }}</ref> He featured heavily with the team during the winter months and he ended the 2009 calendar year by scoring a goal and providing an assist 4–1 win over [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] away at [[Fratton Park]].<ref>{{cite news|title= Portsmouth v Arsenal – as it happened|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/dec/30/arsenal-portsmouth|date=30 December 2009 |first=Tom|last=Lutz |work=The Guardian | location=London | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Samir Nasri Arsenal corner kick.jpg|250px|thumb|left|Nasri taking a [[corner kick]] for Arsenal.]]
After going nearly two months without scoring a goal, Nasri marked his goal-scoring return in emphatic fashion in the team's 5–0 second leg victory over [[FC Porto|Porto]] in the round of 16 of the [[2009–10 UEFA Champions League knockout phase|Champions League knockout stage]]. The goal, described by English newspaper ''[[The Guardian]]'' columnist David Lacey as "reminiscent of a lost art in British football", showcased Nasri's dribbling, as well as his individuality.<ref>{{cite news|title= Samir Nasri's dribbling makes him a throwback to days of Matthews|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2010/mar/13/samir-nasri-dribbling-stanley-matthews|date=13 March 2010 |first=David|last=Lacey |work=The Guardian | location=London | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> Upon receiving the ball on the right wing from [[midfielder]] [[Abou Diaby]], Nasri dribbled through and past three Porto players in a small area of space before bringing the ball past wing-back [[Álvaro Pereira]] and driving it across the goalkeeper, sending the ball in off the far post. Nasri goal was subsequently compared by the English media to similar goals that occurred in the country.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1257047/How-does-Arsenal-striker-Nasri-compare-mazy-masters-Ricky-Villa-John-Barnes-Archie-Gemmill.html|title=How does Arsenal's Samir Nasri compare to mazy masters Ricky Villa, John Barnes and Archie Gemmill?|date=12 March 2010 |accessdate=19 March 2011|location=London|work=Daily Mail|first=Mike|last=Breton}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/09032010/58/champions-league-bendtner-shoots-arsenal-eight.html|title=Champions League – Bendtner shoots Arsenal into last eight|date=9 March 2000|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=9 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nealcollins.co.uk/blog/2010/03/nasri-does-maradona-arsenal-sink-porto.html|title=Nasri does a Maradona, Bendtner does the trick, Arsenal sink Porto in a storm. High-fives all round for Gooners|last=Collins|first=Neal|date=9 March 2010|publisher=Nealcollins.co.uk|accessdate=9 March 2010}}</ref> Three weeks later, after appearing as a substitute in the second half, Nasri scored the opening goal against [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]]. Birmingham later equalized through a late goal from [[Kevin Phillips (footballer)|Kevin Phillips]]. The draw ended a string of seven consecutive league victories for Arsenal and Wenger admitted that the draw "was a big blow for our chances [of winning the league]".<ref>{{cite news|title= Birmingham's Kevin Phillips leaves Arsenal's title hopes in balance|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/mar/27/birmingham-arsenal-premier-league|date=27 March 2010 |first=Anna|last=Kessel |work=The Guardian | location=London | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> In the team's final seven league matches, Nasri assisted on goals in a 3–2 loss to [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] and a 4–0 home win over [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].<ref>{{cite news|title= Wigan fightback stuns Arsenal and shatters lingering title chances|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/apr/18/wigan-athletic-arsenal-premier-league|date=18 April 2010 |first=Joe|last=Lovejoy |work=The Guardian | location=London | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Arsenal outgun flimsy Fulham|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/match_report/0,19764,11065_3151895,00.html|date=9 May 2010 |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> Arsenal ultimately finished the campaign in third place. Nasri concluded his second season at Arsenal appearing in 34 matches, scoring five goals and providing five assists.
==== 2010–11 season ==== [[File:Samir Nasri cross.jpg|260px|thumb|upright|Nasri, in the [[2010–11 in English football|2010–11 season]], delivering a cross.]] Ahead of the [[2010–11 Arsenal F.C. season|2010–11 season]], Nasri admitted he was determined to re-capture his form that resulted in Arsenal signing him two years prior. He also admitted he did not take missing out on the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] well, stating, "When I discovered that I wasn't part of the squad for the World Cup, I got a big slap in the face."<ref>{{cite news|title= Nasri keen to right wrongs|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6302576,00.html|date=9 August 2010 |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> However, after speaking to Arsène Wenger, who informed him he should use the non-call-up as motivation, Nasri was reassured.<ref>{{cite news|title= Wenger urges duo to bounce back|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6198643,00.html|date=9 June 2010 |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> Nasri started the campaign well. He was named in Arsenal's starting line-up to play against Liverpool for the first match of the season on 15 August 2010. Nasri played the entire match in a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite news|title= Pepe Reina howler gives Arsenal a point against 10-man Liverpool|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/aug/15/liverpool-arsenal-premier-league|date=15 August 2010 |first=Kevin|last=McCarra |work=The Guardian | location=London | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> After the match, Arsenal confirmed Nasri had suffered a knee injury that would keep him out for a month.<ref>{{cite news|title= Arsenal dealt Nasri injury blow|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/arsenal-dealt-nasri-injury-blow-2055791.html|date=18 August 2010 |first=Jim|last=van Wijk | accessdate =19 March 2011|location=London|work=The Independent}}</ref> However, the player returned to the team after just three matches to help Arsenal defeat [[S.C. Braga|Braga]] 6–0 in the [[2010–11 UEFA Champions League group stage]] on his return.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000118/match=2002823/index.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100827232909/http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000118/match=2002823/index.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=27 August 2010 |title=Fàbregas lights up Arsenal's night |publisher=[[UEFA]] |date=15 September 2010 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref> On 21 September, he scored a double in the club's 4–1 [[extra time]] victory over [[North London derby]] rivals [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{cite news|title= Andrey Arshavin puts seal on Arsenal's derby destruction of Tottenham|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/sep/21/tottenham-hotspur-arsenal-carling-cup|date=21 September 2010 |first=Kevin|last=McCarra |work=The Guardian | location=London | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> Both goals were converted from the penalty spot. Fours days later, Nasri scored another double in a 3–2 home defeat to West Bromwich Albion.<ref>{{cite news|title= Arsenal 2–3 West Brom |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/9024632.stm|date=25 September 2010 |first=Les|last=Roopanarine |publisher=BBC | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> [[File:SamirNasriEmirates.jpg|190px|thumb|left|Nasri during the 2010–11 season]]
Nasri continued his fine form as season wore on. In the club's Champions League group stage tie against Serbian club [[FK Partizan|Partizan]], he assisted on a [[Sébastien Squillaci]] goal in the team's 3–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000118/match=2002847/index.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100827233015/http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000118/match=2002847/index.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=27 August 2010 |title=Late goals earn Arsenal the points at Partizan |publisher=[[UEFA]] |date=28 September 2010 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref> In October 2010, Nasri went on a streak in which he scored goals in three-straight matches. He started the streak by converting a penalty in a 2–1 win over Birmingham City.<ref>{{cite news|title= Chamakh strikes to lift Arsenal against Birmingham as Wilshere sees red|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/oct/16/arsenal-birmingham-city-premier-league|date=16 October 2010 |first=Dominic|last=Fifield |work=The Guardian | location=London | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> In the club's following match, against [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk|Shakhtar Donetsk]], Nasri scored on a left-footed volley in a 5–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000118/match=2002864/index.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100827232444/http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000118/match=2002864/index.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=27 August 2010 |title=Sizzling Arsenal sweep Shakhtar aside |publisher=[[UEFA]] |date=19 October 2010 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref> He also assisted on a goal in the match. Against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] five days later, he scored the first goal and set up the third in a 3–0 victory.<ref>{{cite news|title= Arsenal lead Manchester City a merry dance after Boyata takes early leave|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/oct/24/manchester-city-arsenal-premier-league|date=24 October 2010 |first=Kevin|last=McCarra |work=The Guardian | location=London | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> As a result of his performances in October 2010, Nasri was named the [[Professional Footballers' Association|PFA]] Fans' Player of the Month.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/nasri-named-pfa-fans-player-of-the-month |title=Nasri named PFA Fans' Player of the Month |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=2 November 2010 |accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> In November, Nasri was on the score-sheet again netting the opener in a 3–2 defeat to Tottenham.<ref>{{cite news|title= Younes Kaboul completes remarkable second-half comeback by Tottenham|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/nov/20/arsenal-tottenham-hotspur-premier-league|date=20 November 2010 |first=Paul|last=Doyle |work=The Guardian | location=London | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> A week later, he scored a volley in a 4–2 win over [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]].<ref>{{cite news|title= Aston Villa outmanoeuvred as Arsenal hit their peak|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/nov/29/aston-villa-arsenal-premier-league|date=29 November 2010 |first=David|last=Lacey |work=The Guardian | location=London | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref>
On 4 December, Nasri scored two goals against Fulham to give Arsenal a 2–1 win. The victory placed Arsenal at the top of the league table.<ref>{{cite news|title= Arsenal 2–1 Fulham |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/9239604.stm|date=4 December 2010 |first=Chris|last=Whyatt |publisher=BBC | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> The two goals were Nasri's seventh and eighth goals, respectively, in the league and his tenth and 11th overall. Just four days later, Nasri scored a goal in Arsenal's vital last group match against Partizan, a 3–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000118/match=2002903/index.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100827233228/http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000118/match=2002903/index.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=27 August 2010 |title=Walcott settles Arsenal nerves to seal passage |publisher=[[UEFA]] |date=8 December 2010 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref> On 13 December, for his performances during the 2010 calendar year, Nasri was named the ''[[France Football]]'' [[France Football#French Player of the Year|French Player of the Year]], edging [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] midfielder [[Florent Malouda]] and Lyon goalkeeper [[Hugo Lloris]]. He became the first Arsenal player to achieve the honour since [[Thierry Henry]] in 2006.<ref name="nasri_player"/> Nasri was also rewarded domestically for his performances in December, winning the Fans' Player of the Month for the second time in the season and also capturing the club's monthly award.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/36360/nasri-named-pfa-fans-player-of-the-month |title=Nasri named PFA Fans' Player of the Month |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=6 January 2011 |accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> He won the award for the second consecutive month in January.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/875377/samir-nasri-claims-back-to-back-espn-pfa-fans%27-awards?cc=5901 |title=Nasri claims back-to-back PFA awards |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/36878/nasri-named-pfa-fans-player-of-the-month |title=Nasri named PFA Fans' Player of the Month |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref>
Nasri scored his 13th goal of the season in the 3–0 win against Birmingham City on 1 January 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title= Arsenal rise above predictable provocation from Birmingham's Lee Bowyer|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/jan/03/birmingham-arsenal-premier-league|date=3 January 2011 |first=Joe|last=Lovejoy |work=The Guardian | location=London | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> In the [[2010–11 FA Cup|FA Cup]], Nasri scored his first-ever goal in the competition in a 3–1 win over [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] in the third round.<ref>{{cite news|title= Samir Nasri dumps Leeds out to kick start Arsenal's FA Cup drive|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/jan/19/leeds-united-arsenal-fa-cup?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487|date=19 January 2011 |first=Kevin|last=McCarra |work=The Guardian | location=London | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> On 30 January, Nasri was forced to leave the team's fourth round FA Cup tie against [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] due to a hamstring injury.<ref>{{cite news|title= Nasri injured as Arsenal edge victory over Huddersfield |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/fa-cup/nasri-injured-as-arsenal-edge-victory-over-huddersfield-15068449.html|date=31 January 2011 |work=[[Belfast Telegraph]] | location=Belfast | accessdate =19 March 2011}}</ref> He subsequently missed two weeks and returned to the team ahead of its Champions League knockout round tie with Spanish champions [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]]. In the first leg, Nasri assisted the match-winning goal scored by [[Andrey Arshavin]]. Arsenal won the match 2–1, but lost the tie 4–3 on aggregate after suffering a 3–1 defeat at the [[Camp Nou]] in the second leg.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000119/match=2003758/index.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101219230415/http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000119/match=2003758/index.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 December 2010 |title=Barcelona rocked by stunning Arsenal comeback |publisher=[[UEFA]] |date=16 February 2011 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000119/match=2003764/index.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101222015020/http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000119/match=2003764/index.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=22 December 2010 |title=Brilliant Barcelona outgun ten-man Arsenal |publisher=[[UEFA]] |date=8 March 2011 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}</ref> On 8 April, Nasri was nominated for both the [[PFA Players' Player of the Year]] and [[PFA Young Player of the Year]] awards.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/clubfootball/news/newsid=1414730.html |title=Bale, Nasri lead PFA nominations |publisher=[[FIFA]] |date=8 April 2011 |accessdate=19 April 2011}}</ref> He lost out on both awards to Tottenham midfielder [[Gareth Bale]] and teammate [[Jack Wilshere]], respectively, but was given consolation with an appearance on the association's [[PFA Team of the Year|Team of the Year]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/748859|title=Arsenal FC: A Tribute to Samir Ben-Said Nasri|website=Bleacher Report.com}}</ref>
Of his time at [[Emirates Stadium]], Nasri has expressed deep admiration for his former manager Wenger, of whom he also described as a "role model" and a "magician". Altogther, Nasri scored 27 goals in 124 total appearances for Arsenal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/289179.html|title=Wenger is a "magician" says Nasri|website=ESPN.co uk}}</ref>
===Manchester City=== [[File:Nasri & Aguero with trophy.JPG|thumb|Nasri (left) and [[Sergio Agüero]] parade the Premier League trophy, May 2012.]]On 24 August 2011, it was confirmed Nasri had joined Premier League club [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/wenger-the-reasons-why-nasri-left-arsenal |title=Wenger: The reasons why Nasri left Arsenal |publisher=[[Arsenal F.C.]] |date=24 August 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> The transfer fee was priced in the region of £25 million, and the player signed a four-year contract.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/948020/samir-nasri-completes-manchester-city-switch-from-arsenal?cc=5901 |title=Samir Nasri completes Manchester City switch from Arsenal |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=24 August 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14654077.stm |title=Samir Nasri completes Manchester City move from Arsenal |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=24 August 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref>
====2011–12 season==== Nasri made his club debut on 28 August in a league fixture away to Tottenham Hotspur. In the match, he assisted on three goals as Manchester City cruised to a 5–1 win.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/14606056.stm |title=Tottenham 1–5 Man City |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=28 August 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> In the team's next match following the September international break, Nasri assisted on one of [[Sergio Agüero]]'s three goals in a 3–0 win over Wigan Athletic. On 1 October, he scored his first goal for the club, scoring the third goal in a 4–0 victory<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/sep/10/manchester-city-wigan-athletic-premier-league |title=Manchester City's Sergio Agüero hits hat-trick to sink Wigan Athletic |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |date=10 September 2011 |accessdate=3 October 2011}}</ref> and also assisting on two other goals.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/oct/01/blackburn-rovers-manchester-city-premier-league |title=Steve Kean feels the heat as Manchester City crush Blackburn |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |date=1 October 2011 |accessdate=3 October 2011}}</ref> After nearly two months without a league goal, on 3 December, Nasri scored his second goal for Manchester City, converting a free-kick in a 5–1 win against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15901844.stm |title=Man City 5–1 Norwich |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=3 December 2011 |accessdate=4 December 2011}}</ref> In the following month, Nasri scored his third goal for the club in a 3–2 win against Tottenham.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/16565416.stm |title=Man City 3–2 Tottenham |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=22 January 2012 |accessdate=21 March 2012}}</ref> On 21 March 2012, he scored the game-winning goal in a 2–1 win over Chelsea after receiving a through-ball from teammate [[Carlos Tevez]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17363120 "Man City 2–1 Chelsea"] BBC Sport. 21 March 2012. Retrieved 22 April 2012.</ref> On 22 April, he scored in a 2–0 away win against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17718140 "Wolves 0–2 Man City"] BBC Sport. 22 April 2012. Retrieved 22 April 2012.</ref> On 13 May, Nasri won his first Premier League trophy as Manchester City were crowned [[List of English football champions|Premier League champions]] for the [[2011–12 Premier League|2011–12 season]] after defeating [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] 3–2.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17973148 "Manchester City 3–2 QPR"] BBC Sport. 13 May 2012. Retrieved 15 May 2012.</ref>
====2012–13 season==== At the start of the [[2012–13 Manchester City F.C. season|2012–13 season]], Nasri switched his squad number from 19 to 8. On 12 August, Nasri scored and assisted a goal in the [[2012 FA Community Shield|2012 Community Shield]], a 3–2 win against [[2011–12 FA Cup|FA Cup]] winners Chelsea.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19133978 "Chelsea 2–3 Man City"] BBC Sport. 12 August 2012. Retrieved 19 August 2012.</ref> A week later, on the opening day of the [[2012–13 Premier League]], he scored and assisted again in a 3–2 win against newly promoted [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19231354 "Man City 3–2 Southampton"] BBC Sport. 19 August 2012. Retrieved 19 August 2012.</ref> He then scored against [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] in a 3–1 loss in the [[2012–13 UEFA Champions League group stage|UEFA Champions League group stage]]. In December 2012, Nasri was criticised for not blocking Robin van Persie's winning goal for Manchester United in the [[Manchester Derby]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/premier-league/9727296/Manchester-City-2-Manchester-United-3-match-report.html|title=Manchester City 2 Manchester United 3: match report|date=9 December 2012|work=The Telegraph}}</ref>
In March 2013, after a [[man of the match]] performance in a 4–0 win against Newcastle United, Manchester City manager [[Roberto Mancini]] said he "would like to give [Nasri] a punch" due to his inconsistent form.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/manchester-city-4-0-newcastle-roberto-1795482|title=Happy slapper! Manchester City boss Roberto Mancini wanted to 'punch' Samir Nasri after dazzling display against Newcastle|date=31 March 2013|work=The Mirror}}</ref> On 14 April, Nasri scored the opening goal as City defeated Chelsea 2–1 in the [[2012–13 FA Cup|FA Cup]] semi-final.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/apr/14/chelsea-manchester-city-fa-cup-match-report|title=Manchester City resist late Chelsea siege to face Wigan in Cup final|date=14 April 2013|work=The Guardian}}</ref>
====2013–14 season==== Nasri scored his first goal of the [[2013–14 Manchester City F.C. season|2013–14 season]] in the match against Manchester United in a 4–1 win.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/sep/22/manchester-city-united-premier-league|title=Manchester City make easy work of lacklustre Manchester United|date=22 September 2013|work=The Guardian}}</ref> On 5 November, he provided assists for goals by Sergio Agüero and [[Álvaro Negredo]] as City cruised by [[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]] 5–2 to advance to the knockout stages of the [[2013–14 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] for the first time in club history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/en/report/380739/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=null |title=City progress as Negredo hits three |publisher=ESPNFC |date=5 November 2013 |accessdate=12 May 2014 }}</ref> On 1 December, Nasri scored twice in a 3–0 win over [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/report/367370/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901 |title=Nasri at the double for City |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=1 December 2013 |accessdate=1 December 2013}}</ref>
On 2 March 2014, Nasri scored the second goal as Manchester City defeated [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] 3–1 to win the [[2014 Football League Cup Final|2014 League Cup final]].<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/league-cup/10670830/Manchester-City-v-Sunderland-Capital-One-Cup-final-as-it-happened.html|title= Manchester City v Sunderland, Capital One Cup final: as it happened|date=2 March 2014|work=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=3 March 2014}}</ref> For his performance in the final, Nasri received the [[Alan Hardaker Trophy]], given to the Man of the Match.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/samir-nasri-just-start-manchester-6763335 |title=Nasri: This is just the start |work=Manchester Evening News |date=3 March 2014 |accessdate=12 May 2014 }}</ref>
In a crucial Premier League match away to [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 3 May, Nasri provided the assist for [[Edin Džeko]]'s game-winning goal as City came from behind to win 3–2 and go top of the table with two matches remaining.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/en/report/367150/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=null |title=Dzeko puts City in box seat |publisher=ESPNFC |date=3 May 2014 |accessdate=12 May 2014 }}</ref> On 11 May, Nasri scored Manchester City's opening goal in a 2–0 defeat of [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] as the club won the [[2013–14 Premier League]] [[List of English football champions|title]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/27273582|title=Man City 2-0 West Ham|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
====2014–15 season==== [[File:Community Shield Nasri corner.jpg|thumbnail|Nasri taking a corner-kick during the [[2014 FA Community Shield]] against Arsenal.]] On 10 July 2014, Nasri signed a new five-year contract deal with Manchester City, which will keep him at the club until 2019.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Team-news/2014/July/Nasri-agrees-new-deal|title=Nasri agrees new five-year deal|date=10 July 2014|accessdate=10 July 2014|publisher=Manchester City F.C.}}</ref>
====2015–16 season==== On 22 November 2015, [[Manuel Pellegrini]] confirmed Nasri would miss four-to-five months of action because of a tendon injury sustained in training.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.90min.com/posts/2736647-manuel-pellegrini-samir-nasri-out-for-five-months|title=Manuel Pellegrini: Samir Nasri out for five months|date=22 November 2015}}</ref> On 10 April 2016, during his first match back from injury, he scored the match-winning goal against West Bromwich Albion as Manchester City won 2–1.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/apr/09/manchester-city-west-bromwich-albion-premier-league-match-report|title=Manchester City back on track for top four as Samir Nasri sees off West Brom|date=10 April 2016}}</ref>
====Loan to Sevilla==== On 31 August 2016, Nasri joined Spanish club [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] on a season-long loan deal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mancity.com/news/first-team/2016/08/31/nasri-joins-sevilla-on-loan/1472639088242|title=Nasri joins Sevilla on loan|publisher=Manchester City F.C.|date=31 August 2016|access-date=31 August 2016}}</ref>
===Antalyaspor=== On 21 August 2017, Nasri signed for Turkish side [[Antalyaspor]] on a two-year contract for a reported €3.5 million transfer fee.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.antalyaspor.com.tr/haber/hos_geldin_samir_nasri_2017-08-21_150432|title=Hoş Geldin Samir Nasri}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40991250|title=Samir Nasri: Manchester City midfielder joins Turkey's Antalyaspor|date=21 August 2017|publisher=BBC Sport|access-date=21 August 2017|language=en-GB}}</ref> On 31 January 2018, Nasri mutually terminated his contract with the club, having made eight appearances and scored two goals in the [[2017–18 Süper Lig|Süper Lig]] during his five-month stay.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://talksport.com/football/former-arsenal-midfielder-samir-nasri-terminates-contract-antalyaspor-180131270736|title=Former Arsenal midfielder Samir Nasri terminates contract with Antalyaspor|work=talksport.com|date=31 January 2018}}</ref>
===Doping ban===
On 22 February 2018, Nasri was given a six-month ban from football by [[UEFA]], for breaching [[World Anti-Doping Agency|WADA]] rules in December 2016 by receiving an intravenous drip of 500 millilitres of water containing nutrients.<ref>{{cite web|title=Samir Nasri given six-month ban for doping violation over drip treatment|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/27/samir-nasri-given-six-month-ban-for-doping-violation-over-drip-treatment|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=6 March 2018}}</ref> On 1 August 2018, Nasri's ban was increased by an extra 12 months following an appeal from UEFA's ethics and disciplinary inspector. The ban was back-dated to 1 July 2017.<ref>{{cite web |title=Samir Nasri: Ex-Man City midfielder's doping ban extended to 18 months |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45039812 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=2 August 2018}}</ref>
===West Ham United=== With his ban from football due to finish on 31 December 2018, Nasri began training with [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] and undertook a medical in the hopes of signing a short-term contract.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/samir-nasri-undergoes-west-ham-medical-ahead-of-80000aweek-deal-a3987556.html|title=Samir Nasri undergoes West Ham medical ahead of £80,000-a-week deal|accessdate=12 November 2018|publisher=Evening Standard|date=12 November 2018}}</ref> When the sanction ended, Nasri signed a short-term deal with West Ham until the end of the [[2018–19 West Ham United F.C. season|2018–19 season]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46700310 |title=West Ham: Samir Nasri signs for Hammers on day doping ban ends |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=31 December 2018 |website=BBC Sport |publisher= |access-date=31 December 2018 |quote=}}</ref>
== International career ==
=== Youth === Nasri has earned caps with all of [[France national youth football team|France's youth teams]] for which he was eligible. He is a member of the group, commonly known as the "''Génération 1987''" which produced internationals [[Hatem Ben Arfa]], [[Karim Benzema]] and [[Jérémy Ménez]], alongside himself.<ref name="nasri_scout"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://fr.fifa.com/confederationscup/news/newsid=613465.html | title = Benzema, Nasri, Ben Arfa, Ménez: le carré d'as de la génération 1987 |date= 11 October 2007 | accessdate =22 March 2011 | publisher=[[FIFA]] | language = French}}</ref> With the [[France national under-16 football team|under-16 team]], Nasri made 16 appearances and scored eight goals. Of the four players, Nasri was the first player to become a regular starter in the team under coach François Blaquart and made his debut in the team's opening match of the campaign against [[Spain national under-16 football team|Spain]]. France won the match 3–0.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m16ans/33030.shtml | title = Premier match réussi pour les Tricolores (3–0)! |date= 18 September 2002 | accessdate =19 March 2011 | publisher=[[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref> Nasri scored his first goal for the team on 29 October in its first group stage match against [[Sweden national under-16 football team|Sweden]] at the ''Tournoi du Val-de-Marne''.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m16ans/actualite/36451.shtml | title = Premier rendez-vous réussi face à la Suède (4–2) |date= 29 October 2002 | accessdate =19 March 2011 | publisher=[[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref> On 11 December, Nasri scored the opening goal in the team's 6–1 defeat of [[Greece national under-16 football team|Greece]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m16ans/40021.shtml | title = La France termine l'année en beauté face à la Grèce (6–1) |date= 11 December 2002 | accessdate =19 March 2011 | publisher=[[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref> At the 2003 Aegean Cup in Turkey, he scored two goals in four matches as France finished the competition in third place. Nasri scored in the team's second group stage match against [[Israel national under-16 football team|Israel]], a 3–1 win.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m16ans/41839.shtml | title = La France se reprend face à Israël (3–1) |date= 8 January 2003 | accessdate =19 March 2011 | publisher=[[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref> In the next group stage match, he scored a goal in 5–0 win over the [[Ukraine national under-16 football team|Ukraine]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m16ans/42113.shtml | title = Les tricolores dominent l'Ukraine (5–0) |date= 10 January 2003 | accessdate =19 March 2011 | publisher=[[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref> In the third place match against [[Belgium national under-16 football team|Belgium]], Nasri assisted on a goal scored by Ben Arfa.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m16ans/42275.shtml | title = La France termine troisième (3–2) |date= 12 January 2003 | accessdate =19 March 2011 | publisher=[[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref> At the [[Montaigu Tournament|Tournoi de Montaigu]], Nasri scored his only goal in the team's 8–0 win over Gabon in the team's opening group match.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m16ans/51364.shtml | title = Entrée en matière réussie face au Gabon (8–0) |date= 16 April 2003 | accessdate =19 March 2011 | publisher=[[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref> France finished the competition runner-up to [[Italy national under-16 football team|Italy]], who defeated France 5–1 in the final match.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m16ans/51741.shtml | title = L'Italie bat la France en finale (5–1) |date= 21 April 2003 | accessdate =19 March 2011 | publisher=[[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref>
At [[France national under-17 football team|under-17 level]], Nasri, Menez and Ben Arfa were joined by Karim Benzema and tasked with the goal of winning the [[2004 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]] on home soil. Nasri made his debut with the team in the opening match of the season against [[Sweden national under-17 football team|Sweden]], scoring a goal in a 5–2 victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m17ans/64527.shtml | title = Un premier test réussi face à la Suède (5–2) |date= 23 September 2003 | accessdate =19 March 2011 | publisher=[[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref> In the team's second straight yearly appearance at the ''Tournoi du Val-de-Marne'', Nasri scored his lone goal in the competition against the [[United States national under-17 football team|United States]] in a 2–0 win as France were declared champions without conceding a goal.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m17ans/actualite/71709.shtml | title = La France remporte le Tournoi du Val-de-Marne! |date= 1 November 2003 | accessdate =19 March 2011 | publisher=[[French Football Federation]] | language = French}}</ref> At the 2004 UEFA European Under-17 Championship, Nasri scored against [[Portugal national under-17 football team|Portugal]] in the competition's semi-finals. France went on to win the match 3–1 to earn a place in the final.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/under17/history/season=2004/round=1658/match=75064/index.html |title=Flamboyant hosts earn final chance |date=9 May 2004 |accessdate=19 March 2011 |publisher=[[UEFA]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160115024746/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/under17/history/season%3D2004/round%3D1658/match%3D75064/index.html |archivedate=15 January 2016 }}</ref> In the final match, France faced [[Spain national under-17 football team|Spain]]. In the match, Nasri scored the game-winning goal to give France its first-ever title in the competition.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/under17/history/season=2004/round=1661/match=75439/index.html |title=Châteauroux celebrates French win |date=15 May 2004 |accessdate=19 March 2011 |publisher=[[UEFA]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131116000441/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/under17/history/season=2004/round=1661/match=75439/index.html |archivedate=16 November 2013 }}</ref> In total with the under-17s, he made 16 appearances and scored six goals. Due to increased playing time at his parent club Marseille, Nasri's stint with the [[France national under-18 football team|under-18 team]] was uneventful, appearing in only four matches.
The foursome of Nasri, Ben Arfa, Benzema and Ménez returned to international play together for [[France national under-19 football team|under-19]] duty. The four were joined by [[Issiar Dia]], [[Blaise Matuidi]] and [[Serge Gakpé]] with the objective of winning the [[2006 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]]. The team opened the campaign with two friendly matches against [[Norway national under-19 football team|Norway]].
